ABSTRACT

SILVA JR, Lourinaldo Soares. Study of operational charge of glycerin by modelin and simulation. Dissertation ( Master's Degree in Chemical and Biochemical Process Engineering). Chemistry School, Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, 2022.

Biodiesel production in Brazil, boosted by the growing demand for renewable energy sources and government policies, has expanded greatly since the last decade. The profit margin for the production of this biofuel is low, mainly due to the high value of conventional raw materials. For the company to keep competitive, some measures are required, such as reducing operating costs and adding greater value to co - products, which is the case of glycerin, a co -product of biodiesel production, whose market value is influenced by its composi tion. The present work proposes the rigorous modeling of a distillation column for the separation of glycerin, methanol, water and olein, with the objective of reducing the operational cost and reducing the humidity of the commercialized glycerin. The liqu id-liquid balance was modeled by the UNIFAC - LLE model, by determining the interaction groups and subgroups. The vapor -liquid equilibrium was modeled by the modified Raoult law. The mass and energy balances at each theoretical stage were determined by the M ESH equations (Material balance equations, Equilibrium phase equations, Summation equations and Heat balance equations). The MESH equations result in obtaining a tridiagonal matrix, which is solved by the Thomas algorithm. The sum -rates model was used as t he algorithm for column modeling. Actual column operation data was exported from PI datalink. For the statistical treatment and validation of the model, 532 laboratory samples of the glycerin outlet moisture, which is the target parameter, were compared wi th the other variables. Data distribution, statistically significant relationships and variables of greater influence were verified. The most significant variables were selected and modified in the model proposed in SCILAB for comparison and analysis with real operating data. The statistical results of the comparison were satisfactory, allowing the use of the model to predict the humidity.
Keywords: Modeling, Distillation, Glycerin, Biodiesel and sum-rates.
